problem.markdown:
>>Given that the system starts at state 1 and p = 0.9 for the two-state system presented in slide 21 (Video 3), at what time is it equally probable for the system to be either in state 0 or state 1? <<
= 0.301 +-5%
[explanation] \(\frac{1}{2} = (1-p)^t\)
\(log(\frac{1}{2}) = t*log(1-p)\)
\(t = \frac{(log(\frac{1}{2}))}{(log(1-p))}\)
If \(p = 0.9 → t = 0.301\)
[explanation]
